channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Young voters could be key to midterm success, but they've soured on both parties
item.description: As Republicans and Democrats gear up for next year's midterm elections, new polling shows they're losing ground with a powerful and growing bloc of the electorate: young voters.
item.content:encoded: As Republicans and Democrats gear up for next year's midterm elections, new polling shows they're losing ground with a powerful and growing bloc of the electorate: young voters.
item.dc:creator: Elena Moore

item.title: Why a classic wide-screen movie format from the 1950s is making a comeback
item.description: VistaVision is back in style, resurfacing in a string of high-profile films from One Battle After Another and Bugonia to last year's The Brutalist.
item.content:encoded: VistaVision is back in style, resurfacing in a string of high-profile films from One Battle After Another and Bugonia to last year's The Brutalist.
item.dc:creator: Mandalit del Barco

item.title: Afghan 'Zero Unit' fighters in the U.S. faced despair before National Guard attack
item.description: Many Afghan "Zero Unit" fighters who served under the CIA now feel they are being abandoned after seeking asylum in the U.S. They've faced despair and isolation - and some have taken their own lives.
item.content:encoded: Many Afghan "Zero Unit" fighters who served under the CIA now feel they are being abandoned after seeking asylum in the U.S. They've faced despair and isolation - and some have taken their own lives.
item.dc:creator: Brian Mann

item.title: HIPAA protects patient privacy, but some say it shuts out caregivers
item.description: The federal HIPAA law protects patient privacy, but some say it can shut out family members trying to help relatives who are experiencing mental health crises.
item.content:encoded: The federal HIPAA law protects patient privacy, but some say it can shut out family members trying to help relatives who are experiencing mental health crises.
item.dc:creator: Maxwell David Howard

item.title: A divided Fed cuts interest rates for third straight time
item.description: The Federal Reserve voted to cut its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday. This was the Fed's third rate cut since September, but policymakers signaled they expect to make fewer rate cuts next year.
item.content:encoded: The Federal Reserve voted to cut its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday. This was the Fed's third rate cut since September, but policymakers signaled they expect to make fewer rate cuts next year.
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: Trump's redistricting push finds resistance in Indiana
item.description: Republican-led states have raced to redraw congressional lines to advantage their own party. But the effort hit unexpected pushback in Indiana.
item.content:encoded: Republican-led states have raced to redraw congressional lines to advantage their own party. But the effort hit unexpected pushback in Indiana.
item.dc:creator: Sam Gringlas

item.title: Oldest evidence of human fire-making unearthed in Britain
item.description: A new study suggests humans were deliberately starting and using fires more than 400,000 years ago.
item.content:encoded: A new study suggests humans were deliberately starting and using fires more than 400,000 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Nathan Rott

item.title: Why news organizations are suing AI companies, and what they hope to win
item.description: The New York Times and Chicago Tribune sued Perplexity last week, the latest in a series of publishers suing AI companies in a bid to set boundaries around a new technology powered by information.
item.content:encoded: The New York Times and Chicago Tribune sued Perplexity last week, the latest in a series of publishers suing AI companies in a bid to set boundaries around a new technology powered by information.
item.dc:creator: John Ruwitch

item.title: New Miami mayor-elect on 'trickle-down hatred' of federal immigration policy
item.description: NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with Miami Mayor-elect Eileen Higgins, who will be the city's first female mayor and the first Democrat in decades to hold the seat.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with Miami Mayor-elect Eileen Higgins, who will be the city's first female mayor and the first Democrat in decades to hold the seat.
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Marquez Janse

item.title: This strategy is creating some tension within the Republican party
item.description: As the GOP looks at 2025 election results, it's sounding a proverbial alarm ahead of the midterms on messaging, particularly on the economy as President Trump shies away from the term "affordability."
item.content:encoded: As the GOP looks at 2025 election results, it's sounding a proverbial alarm ahead of the midterms on messaging, particularly on the economy as President Trump shies away from the term "affordability."
item.dc:creator: Stephen Fowler
